Although they have already come from other places, they have not yet reached the Eastern Temple.
For this reason, I diligently copied them to the best of my ability and requested them.
If I think of increasing blessings for the state,
and opening the way for the temple,
I humbly repay the kindness of my late master in transmitting the teachings,
and provide for the study of Dharma by later generations.
The purpose of making pilgrimages and requesting teachings is not empty.

The above implements and relics are the necessities for practitioners.
There is no accomplishment in the practice of siddhi that does not rely on these.

From the sixth month to the tenth month of the sixth year of the Xiané€š era of the Great Tang Dynasty,
at the Ximing Temple on the right street of Chang'an City, the Japanese monk Enzai, who stayed to study Buddhism, requested to copy various Dharma gates and other catalogs as listed above.
On the 12th day of the 11th month of the 7th year of the Japanese Tenryaku era, he returned to the Eastern Temple in the left capital to re-examine and determine.
The great Dharma master who came to Tang to study Buddhism wrote a postscript.
